header.title: The Magick of Kirani King of Persia, and of Harpocration
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Natural Magic, Medical Magic

central_thesis: This text presents a comprehensive system of natural magic and medicine, asserting that various natural objects—stones, herbs, fishes, beasts, and birds—possess inherent 'Magical and Medicinal Vertues' derived from divine wisdom and celestial influences. These virtues can be harnessed through specific preparations and applications for a wide range of practical purposes, including healing, protection, love, success, and divination, without recourse to 'diabolical contract'.

structure_content.summary: The 'Reader's' introduction establishes the book's rarity and disputed provenance, discussing its alleged presence in the Vatican Library and its translation from Persian, Syriac, and Arabic into Greek and English. It clarifies the authors (Kiranus, King of Persia, and Harpocration, a Grecian) and positions the work as 'natural magic'—a skill based on 'created' rather than 'supernatural' powers, distinct from diabolical pacts. The introduction also hints at the book's alphabetical organization and its focus on the 'Magical and Medicinal Vertues' of various natural substances.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Epistle Dedicatory of the Old Interpreter (pages 9-12)
structure_content.summary: This dedication from the 'Old Interpreter' (translator) to a 'Prudent Mr. Ra. Pa.' emphasizes the book's value and the 'Divine Dignity' of its contents. It describes the text's composition in Syriac letters on an iron pillar and its subsequent translation. The text highlights that 'the invention or beginning is from Almighty GOD,' asserting that 'the knowledge & skill of many things comes from GOD into men' through understanding the 'mutual permixtions' and 'Proprieties' of natural elements. It urges secrecy, advising that the book should only be passed to children for its efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Book I: KIRANIDES and HARPOCRATION (Letters A-Ω, pages 13-64)
structure_content.summary: This foundational section presents an alphabetical encyclopedia of natural items—stones, herbs, fishes, beasts, and birds—detailing their specific magical and medicinal properties. Each entry (e.g., 'Ampelos Leukē' for white Vine, 'Aetos' for Eagle) outlines the item's nature, 'virtues,' and practical applications for various ailments (e.g., convulsions, bloody flux, head-aches, leprosy) or desired outcomes (e.g., amiability, sobriety, dispelling devils, sharpening sight, enhancing memory). Methods involve wearing engraved stones, consuming preparations, or applying salves. Many entries explicitly link virtues to celestial influences or 'Divine Efficacy.'

Continuing the alphabetical format, this book focuses on a range of animals (e.g., She-Goat, Cow, Weasel, Roe-buck, Hedgehog, Cat, Deer, Mule, Spider, Horse, Camel, Dog, Wolf, Mouse, Bat, Crocodile, Ass, Sheep, Rhinoceros, Wild Boar, Bull, Hyena, Seal, Chameleon, Sand-Spider, Sea-Flea), detailing their unique virtues. It provides practical instructions for healing, protection against physical and spiritual dangers, influencing love and conception, and even specific divinatory practices, often emphasizing precise preparation, application, and timing (e.g., lunar phases, specific body parts for amulets).

This book primarily focuses on birds (e.g., Eagle, Vultur, Woodpecker, Stork, Thistle-bird, Sun-Bird, Hawk, Raven, Crow, Sea-Gull, Lapwing, Duck, Hen, Pelican, Sparrow, Water-wagtail, Peacock, Turtle, Parrot, Starling, Goose, Owl) and their magical and medicinal uses. It details how different bird parts (heart, tongue, feathers, dung, eggs) can be prepared and used to achieve various effects: curing physical ailments (head-aches, gout, bloody flux), providing protection (from devils, storms, enemies), granting foreknowledge and eloquence, and influencing love and fertility. Timing and specific rituals are frequently prescribed.

This book concentrates on fishes and other aquatic creatures (e.g., Eagle-fish, Sea-Urchin, Remora, Eel, Dolphin, Dragon-fish, Mullet, Carp, Shrimp, River-Crabs, Lobster, Sea-Cockles, Herring, Pilchards, Ruff, Cramp-fish, Pickerel, Sea-Ass, Palours, Sea-Lungs, Stock-fish, Cuttle-fish, Tooth-fish, Sea-barbel, Water Snake) and their diverse applications. It offers remedies for numerous diseases (e.g., quartan agues, pimples, carbuncles, gout, leprosy, head-aches, kidney stones, impotence), as well as methods for protection, dispelling devils, influencing love, and sharpening senses. The preparation and use often involve specific parts of the creature, mixed with other ingredients, and applied or consumed in particular ways.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Table of Diseases, and their Remedies (pages 94-97)
structure_content.summary: An index that cross-references specific diseases and conditions with the page numbers where their remedies are described throughout the four books. This section serves as a practical guide for practitioners seeking cures for various ailments, demonstrating the medicinal focus of the grimoire.

An index listing the Greek names of the stones, herbs, birds, and fishes mentioned in each of the first three books, categorized alphabetically. This helps users navigate the extensive catalog of natural items and their corresponding entries.

key_concepts.definition: Inherent properties of natural objects (stones, herbs, animals) that can be harnessed for practical effects. These virtues are believed to originate from divine wisdom and celestial influences, rather than diabolical means.

The core principle governing the interaction and application of natural substances. Items are chosen based on their natural affinities or repulsions to specific conditions, ailments, or desired outcomes, often linked to planetary correspondences or observed natural behaviors (e.g., Ivy defending the brain from drunkenness).

Specific images (e.g., animals, Bacchus, Venus, Mars, or abstract symbols) engraved onto stones or other materials (often metal, bone, or skin) to activate, direct, or concentrate their magical virtues. These prepared items are then worn on the body or placed in specific locations to achieve desired effects such as protection, healing, or influence.

A system of magic explicitly defined as drawing its power from the inherent, created virtues of nature and celestial influences. It is distinguished from 'diabolical contract' and emphasizes 'the Skill of managing Nature by Art' to accomplish 'strange things' whose causes are 'beyond the common Comprehension of Men.'

The astrological or planetary forces that imbue natural objects with their specific virtues. The efficacy of magical operations often depends on precise timing aligned with lunar phases (e.g., 'Moon in the Wane', 'full Moon'), solar positions (e.g., 'Sun in Aries'), or specific days and hours, reflecting a microcosmic-macrocosmic correspondence.

The ability to perceive future events, hidden truths, or secrets. Certain preparations, such as wearing specific amulets, anointing with particular compounds, or performing rituals before sleep, are said to grant prophetic dreams or direct awareness of future happenings.

A recurring instruction emphasizing that the knowledge and methods described in the book, particularly the more potent ones, should be kept secret from the ignorant and transmitted only to trusted heirs or suitable initiates, preserving the 'great Possession' and preventing misuse or loss of efficacy.

practical_system.description: The practical system is built upon a philosophy of universal correspondences, where every natural object—stones, herbs, fishes, beasts, and birds—possesses specific 'Magical and Medicinal Vertues' imparted by divine wisdom and celestial influences. These virtues are activated and directed through precise preparation, application, and timing, often involving sympathetic magic (e.g., using a lion's part for courage) and astrological alignment. The magic is explicitly 'natural,' eschewing diabolical intervention, and aims to control natural forces for healing, protection, love, success, and foreknowledge.

rituals: Preparation of substances: Boiling, drying, powdering, grinding, bruising, roasting, burning to ash, mixing with various ingredients (honey, oils, wine, vinegar, salt, animal fats, spices, other herbs/animal parts), creating electuaries, plasters, ointments, salves, suffumigations, or tinctures.

Application of items: Wearing amulets or talismans (phylacteries, ligatures), often engraved stones or animal parts encased in skins, cloths, or gold, on specific body parts (neck, arm, breast, twist, girdle) or as rings.
Consumption: Drinking prepared substances with water, wine, broth, or other liquids, or eating them, often with specific dietary restrictions or requirements (e.g., fasting, chastity).
Anointing: Applying ointments or prepared liquids to the body, head, face, eyes, or specific affected areas.

Timing: Performing rituals or preparing items according to specific astrological phases (e.g., Moon in the Wane, full Moon), solar positions (e.g., Sun in Aries), days of the week (e.g., Sabbath day), or hours.

Engraving/Inscribing: Carving images (e.g., animals, Bacchus, Venus, Mars) or writing specific names/words onto stones, metal, bone, or skin to imbue them with power. These are then often worn or kept.

Divinatory practices: Placing specific items under the head before sleep to induce prophetic dreams, anointing the face or body to gain foreknowledge, or performing specific actions (e.g., animal sacrifice, observing animal behavior) for omens.
Protection and aversion: Specific items worn, consumed, or placed in homes or ships to ward off devils, evil spirits, phantasms, witchcraft, storms, dangers, thieves, or enemies.
Secrecy: Adherence to strict secrecy regarding certain powerful preparations and rituals, to be shared only with 'sacred Children' or trusted individuals.

relevant_quotes.text: CONTAINING THE Magical and Medicinal Vertues of Stones, Herbs, Fishes, Beasts and Birds.
A Work much sought for by the Learned, but seen by few; said to have been in the Vatican-Library in Rome; but not to be found there, nor in all the Famous Libraries of the Empire.
This work of his had been for many Ages turned out of the Persian into the Syriack, Arabick, and most Eastern Tongues.
Magick I seem to be a skill which by a certain Power, yet not supernatural, but created, is able to do unusual things, whose Causes are beyond the common Comprehension of Men.
And by excluding from it all Diabolical Contract, we must intend to other than Magick purely natural, or the Skill of managing Nature by Art, so as to accomplish strange things.

Do not therefore deliver it to the Ignorant, but keep it to thy self as a great Possession: and let the Father, if it may so be, deliver it only to his Children instead of Gold for the efficacy of its Action, adjuring them, as sacred Children, only to keep it secret.

The invention or beginning is from Almighty GOD; for by his Wisdom we obtain the Action of Herbs, Fishes and Birds, and the Virtue of Stones, and the Nature of Animals and wild Beasts, and moreover, the mutual permixtions of them, and their Communities and Proprieties, since the knowledge & skill of many things comes from GOD into men.

That you may be without Drunkenness, and for all favour and health; In the Stone Thyrsites engrave the Bird Thyr, and Bacchus holding the Bird, and under the stone enclose the Root of the Herb, (meaning Ivy) and wear it, and you will be...

critical_analysis.relevance: The Magick of Kirani and Harpocration is a highly relevant text within the study of Western Esotericism, particularly for understanding the grimoire tradition and the historical intersection of natural magic with early modern medicine and science. It exemplifies a genre of practical magic that sought to harness hidden virtues of nature through correspondences, distinct from overtly demonological grimoires. Its emphasis on 'natural means' positions it within a strand of acceptable magical practice in its historical context, providing a rich primary source for exploring pre-Enlightenment cosmological views, aetiology of disease, and the role of hidden powers in health and daily life. The detailed catalog of substances and their applications offers insight into the practical beliefs and methods of natural philosophers and magicians of the era.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, particularly those interested in historical grimoires, natural magic, and the Hermetic tradition. Additionally, it would be valuable for historians of science and medicine, folklorists, and anyone studying the history of popular beliefs about health, protection, and divination. For operative magicians, it offers a system of natural remedies and enchantments based on traditional correspondences, with explicit instructions for practical application.
